Dear Roman Kolodchin:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Shay Mavis at 269-243-2725.
Sincerely,
Erica Marshall, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health Services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(d) Storage of medications.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Upon admission to the facility, a staff member left medication
unsecured with a youth who ingested them and required
emergency medical attention.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 4/22/25. There
was no additional information reported regarding the incident.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at Health Source
Saginaw on 4/23/25 by Courtesy MDHHS Worker. Consultant
and MDHHS Worker were present via phone. Youth A reported
after the admission process was completed, the Foster Care
Specialist handed Youth A’s medication to Staff 1, who then
placed the medication on the staff desk. Youth A reported Staff 1
walked away to prepare Youth A’s room, while Youth A, the Foster
Care Specialist, and Support Staff remained near the desk. Youth
A reported Staff 1 was ready to take her to her room. Youth A
reported she initially ran outside because she did not want to stay.
Support Staff and Foster Care Specialist ran after her to prevent
her from leaving without permission, but Youth A ran back inside
to the admission office after remembering her pills were there.
She reported having two pill bottles, each contained in its own
plastic bag. Youth A reported taking one bottle—believed to be
Clonidine—before Support Staff was able to retrieve the rest of
the pills before she ingested any. Support Staff then hugged
Youth A to help calm her down. Youth A reported no other facility
staff were present during this time. She reported running back
inside to grab the other pills because she had been told she had
to stay. Youth A reported she was able to grab the pills and run
past both the Foster Care Specialist and Support Staff. She then
reported ingesting between 10 and 15 pills. Youth A reported that
Staff 1 attempted to approach her to de-escalate the situation, but
she told Staff 1 to stay away and took the pills before anyone
could intervene. She reported that she did not want to die and
informed the others how many pills she had taken, after which
Support Staff called 911.Youth A reported that Staff 1 did not help
and told her she could not remain at the facility if she continued to
behave in that manner. Following the incident, Youth A was
transported by ambulance, spent the night in the hospital, and was
subsequently transferred to another facility.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/28/25.
Youth B reported she was not present to witness the incident
involving Youth A. The admission process was reviewed with
Youth B. She reported being aware of how medication is handled
during both admission process and daily. Youth B reported, during
her admission, she handed her medication to a staff member who
2

completed the admission process, but she was unsure where the
medication was stored afterward. She denied having access to
her medication and stated she asks staff when she needs it.
Youth C was interviewed via face to face at the facility on
4/28/25 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C reported
being at the facility for 4 days and was not a resident at the time of
the incident. Youth C did not come with any medication. Youth C
reported only seeing staff access the medication room.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
4/24/25 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor
reported being unaware of the incident when it occurred and was
not present. Supervisor reported Staff 1 is not under any
disciplinary action and there has not been issues or concerns with
her conduct towards staff and youth.
President was interviewed face to face at the facility on
4/24/25 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. President
reported Youth A was not under the facility’s supervision when the
incident occurred. President was not present when the incident
occurred. President reported the issue should be addressed with
Foster Care Specialist because Youth A was not admitted to the
facility since the admission process was never completed.
President reported Youth A’s medication was handed to Staff 1
during the middle of the admission process, but the process was
not complete. Consultant and MDHHS Worker asked to view the
documents completed during the admission process, but
President reported the documents were not available and she
would provide them later. President was asked how the
medication was placed behind the plastic partition, if Youth A was
not admitted. President reported the paperwork for medication
may have been signed but the packet was not completed for
Youth A to be fully admitted. President reported there are not
cameras inside or outside of the admission office.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 4/24/25 and 4/28/25 in collaboration with MDHHS
Worker. CA reported he was not present for the incident. CA
reported he received a phone call from Staff 1. Upon learning
Youth A was being transported to the hospital, CA instructed Staff
1 to discharge Youth A. CA was adamant that Youth A had not
been fully admitted into the facility. However, CA was later
informed confirmation had been received indicating Youth A was
fully admitted into the program during the admission process.
When asked how a youth could be discharged without being
admitted, the CA acknowledged that he had been misinformed
and apologized for the confusion. CA reported MDHHS (didn’t
3

specify an individual) was trying to cover up the mistake that
happened the day of the incident and believes Foster Care
Specialist was at fault for Youth A being able to ingest her
medication. CA was not present for the incident. CA reported staff
acted appropriately and contacted 911. CA reported there are no
cameras in the admission office or outside of the building. CA
reported no incident report was completed at the time of the event,
as he believed the admission process for Youth A had not been
finalized and, therefore, she had not officially been admitted. He
added that incident reports are typically completed immediately
following an incident.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/28/25
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported Youth A
was brought to the facility by Foster Care Specialist and Support
Staff. Staff 1 reported Youth A did not want to be at the facility and
voiced this concern immediately upon arrival. Staff 1 denied
speaking to Youth A in a disrespectful tone. However, Staff 1
reported informing Youth A the program was voluntary and if she
did not sign the paper, then she could not admit her. Staff 1
reported Youth A along with Foster Care Specialist signed all the
admissions forms necessary to complete the process. Staff 1
stated the medication page is in the middle of the document page
and are instructed to take the medication and leave it on the desk
while the rest of the admission is completed. Staff 1 reported there
are no locked areas in the office to secure the medication, which
is why the medication is left on the desk until the admission is
complete. Staff 1 reported after admission is complete, the
medication is transported by staff to the building where the youth
reside. Staff 1 reported there is no other time the medication is
locked up during the admission process. Staff 1 admitted to
leaving the medication on the desk behind the plastic partition
because this was how she was trained to conduct admissions.
Staff 1 reported she went through Youth A’s clothes after all the
paperwork was signed and Youth A was fully admitted. Staff 1
reported knowing the admission process was complete, because
each document on the IPAD went from red to burgundy which
indicates the process is complete. Staff 1 reported Foster Care
Specialist asked to see Youth A’s room and then Youth A ran out
of the admission office towards the Foster Care Specialist car.
Staff 1 reported Youth A refused to come back into the office.
However, Foster Care Specialist and Support staff were able to
run after Youth A in efforts to deescalate her. Staff 1 reported she
did not go after Youth A, because she went to find a work phone
to call for help. Staff 1 reported she contacted On Call Supervisor
and Chief Administrator. Staff 1 reported Chief Administrator
confirmed Youth A was admitted and gave the approval to
discharge Youth A from the program and to cancel the admission.
4

Staff 1 reported hearing Youth A yelling from the admission office,
and as Staff 1 was going back to the office, Youth A ran past her
and out the door. Staff 1 reported being unaware Youth A had pills
until Support Staff said, “she has the pills”. Staff 1 reported feeling
she was not trained enough to handle such a crisis. Staff 1
reported that she froze and did not know what to do and did not
know Youth A took the pills off the desk. Staff 1 reported she ran
outside and saw Youth A running down the street. Staff 1 reported
Support Staff was able to get Youth A to turn around. Staff 1
reported Youth A ran back towards the admissions office, so Staff
1 asked Youth A to hand over the pills and Youth A gave her a
handful of pills. Staff 1 reported Support Staff also held a pill
bottle. Staff 1 reported Youth A ran back into the admission office,
and Support Staff and Foster Care Specialist followed behind
Youth A. Support Staff was able to de-escalate Youth A for a little
bit before Youth A pushed past Support Staff, grabbed another pill
bottle and a pop, and started taking the pills. Staff 1 reported
Youth A brushed passed Foster Care Specialist (who was at the
door) and ran down the street again. Staff 1 reported staff cannot
leave the street. Foster Care Specialist and Support Staff were
able to catch Youth A approaching 8-mile road from the residential
street. Youth A was then transported by EMS to the hospital.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face on 4/28/25 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported she was not
present during the incident but is familiar with the admissions
process. She explained the process which includes review of the
medication and medication documents. Staff 2 reported the
youths’ parents or guardians’ hand over medication, usually in
pharmacy containers in a clear bag. Staff record the names,
quantities, and dosages of the medication. Staff 2 reported
medication is kept on the desk during admission, as per training,
and passed through or around a plastic partition used for safety.
Medication is not secured until the admission is complete, and the
youth is escorted to their building, where it is then locked up. Staff
2 said she’s never had a youth try to take medication but sees
how it could happen. She expressed concern about inadequate
crisis management training, noting many staff feel unprepared in
high-stress situations and the de-escalation training is not
sufficient.
Foster Care Specialist was interviewed on 4/23/24 via
telephone. Foster Care Specialist reported the admission process
was complete when the incident with Youth A occurred. She
reported Staff 1 went through Youth A’s clothes and offered to
show Foster Care Specialist Youth A’s room. Foster Care
Specialist reported Youth A got upset and did not want to go to
her new room. Foster Care Specialist reported Youth A grabbed
5

the pills off the desk and ran outside. Foster Care Specialist
reported she and Support Staff were able to get the pills from
Youth A’s hands. However, Youth A ran back inside and grabbed
additional pills and ingested them. Foster Care Specialist reported
she was unaware of Staff 1’s whereabouts. Foster Care Specialist
reported Support Staff contacted 911.
Documents Reviewed:
1. Staff 1’s personnel file: There were two disciplinary
actions found in the file, which were unrelated to this
investigation. Staff 1 completed Medication Administrative
and Documentation training on 12/9/24. Competency
training completed on 2/3/25.
2. Medication Storage Policy: Provides general guidelines
to medication storage for residents. All Schedule II –IV
medications are to be locked in a medication cabinet.
3. Admissions Process Policy: Upon admission, the
admitting Director Care Professional (DCP) or Supervisor
will greet the youth. The youth and their personal inventory
will be inspected. All medications must be handed over to
the admitting DCP. The DCP or nurse will review the
medications with the parent or guardian. All medications
must be in their original packaging (e.g., prescription
bottles). Medications will be reported and documented for
both the psychiatrist and nurse and securely stored in the
medication cabinet. The parent or guardian will complete all
required admission forms. The DCP will record all relevant
information in the youth’s electronic chart using the
admissions form. At the conclusion of the process, the DCP
will assign the youth to their designated bed.
4. Direct Care Professional Classification Criteria at
Admission Policy: This policy summarizes how all
admissions are completed by Safehaus trained staff.
During the admission process staff are to assess newly
admitted youth for health concerns, take vitals, inspect
youth’s body for any scars/marks and document areas of
concern, collect and maintain medication, generate a
Medication Administration Record of any prescribed
authorized medication, and document diagnoses and
medical history in admission notes.
5. Incident Report dated 4/17/25 authored by Staff 1: The
incident report aligns with all interviews except for Youth
A’s statement, in which Youth A reported Staff 1 was not
6

present to witness the incident. However, Staff 1 reported
that she was present for approximately 10 minutes when
Youth A initially refused to leave the admissions office to
see her new room. Staff 1 stated that she then left the
admissions office to contact the Chief Administrator about
next steps since Youth A was not cooperative. Staff 1 noted
that Youth A remained in the office with Foster Care
Specialist and Support Staff, and she believed Youth A was
under appropriate supervision.
6. Adverse Incident Procedures: Supervisor on duty should
be notified immediately, and an Adverse Incident Report
form should be completed.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as per interviews
conducted, Staff 1 did not properly secure Youth A’s medication
during the admission process. The facility’s medication storage
policy states medications are to be stored in a locked cabinet.
However, Youth A’s medication was left unlocked and unattended,
which led to Youth A ingesting and overdosing on her medication.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
• The facility was informed they must have a place to safely
secure medications during the admission process.
• The facility should update their admission process/policy
and DCP admission policy to include appropriate
medication storage, which should mirror the facility’s
medication storage policy.
• An incident report was not completed the day of the
incident. The facility was informed they must adhere to their
own policy and complete an incident report immediately
following an incident. Incident report was received on
4/28/25 but dated 4/17/25.
• The facility should explore more in-depth, frequent, and/or
effective crisis intervention/management training as Staff 1
and Staff 2 expressed additional training surrounding crisis
intervention would be beneficial, as they currently felt
unprepared.
• The facility should ensure staff have adequate ways to call
for assistance no matter where they are on the facility’s
grounds, as Staff 1 reported spending time trying to find a
signal so she could call for help during this crisis.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
7

Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the current license status be continued.
